Description: Rim and body sherd (mended from two fragments) of Vroulian pottery cup with everted rim; interior: reserved at rim, glazed black below; top and outside of rim glazed; in reserved handle zone, St. Andrew's crosses alternating with groups of vertical strokes between single bands; glazed below and to right, around lost handle join.
Curator's comments: For parallels, see Kinch (1914), p. 128, fig. 120. The sherd possibly belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1914,0317.5.a, 1914,0317.5.b and 1914,0317.5.e. The sherd belongs in Kinch's Group B 1.α or .β of Vroulian cups. It is impossible to determine to which of the two groups the cup belongs since the defining characteristic is found on the underside of the stemmed foot, which is now lost. According to Schlotzhauer, Vroulian cups with a geometric pattern in the handle zone and with a shape similar to South Ionian cups with everted rims (Schlotzhauer Type 8, which coincides with Vallet and Villiard's Ionian cup type A1 and Hayes' Ionian cup type III) may be contemporary and ought to be dated amongst the earliest examples of Vroulian pottery at Naukratis. Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88 Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GN.06) (phase 3)
